20101222010802.000|20101222010804.000|TR0|supposed to be a party of choices, but how

20101222012353.000|20101222012355.000|TR0|
20101222012355.000|20101222012357.000|TR0|(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
20101222012357.000|20101222012358.000|TR0|
20101222012358.000|20101222012400.000|TR0|PARKER:  In a lame duck session that has 
20101222012400.000|20101222012402.000|TR0|had more than its share of drama, a Senate 
20101222012402.000|20101222012404.000|TR0|vote on the START treaty is in the final 
20101222012404.000|20101222012405.000|TR0|act. START is of course the new Strategic 
20101222012405.000|20101222012407.000|TR0|Arms Reduction Treaty between the United 
20101222012407.000|20101222012409.000|TR0|States and Russia to reduce the size of 
20101222012409.000|20101222012411.000|TR0|each country's nuclear arsenal.       The 
20101222012411.000|20101222012412.000|TR0|treaty was signed by President Obama and 
20101222012412.000|20101222012414.000|TR0|Russian President Medvedev in April of 
20101222012414.000|20101222012416.000|TR0|2010, and it's now waiting approval both 
20101222012416.000|20101222012418.000|TR0|by the U.S. Senate and the Russian 
20101222012418.000|20101222012419.000|TR0|parliament.
20101222012419.000|20101222012421.000|TR0|
20101222012421.000|20101222012423.000|TR0|SPITZER:  Republicans have made their 
20101222012423.000|20101222012425.000|TR0|objections clear, focusing primarily on 
20101222012425.000|20101222012426.000|TR0|their claim that the treaty limits U.S. 
20101222012426.000|20101222012428.000|TR0|capacity to develop and deploy missile 
20101222012428.000|20101222012430.000|TR0|defense systems.  Support for the treaty 
20101222012430.000|20101222012432.000|TR0|is growing, it appears that it will pass 
20101222012432.000|20101222012434.000|TR0|the Senate tomorrow, but it may still face 
20101222012434.000|20101222012435.000|TR0|big problems.
20101222012435.000|20101222012437.000|TR0|

20101222015011.000|20101222015013.000|TR0|fees is so important.

20101222015015.000|20101222015016.000|TR0|BOGLE:  The reason it's important is, in a 
20101222015016.000|20101222015018.000|TR0|very simplified way, if the market gives 
20101222015018.000|20101222015020.000|TR0|an eight percent annual return, we all, 
20101222015020.000|20101222015022.000|TR0|all investors groups divide up eight 
20101222015022.000|20101222015023.000|TR0|percent.  OK.  Not complicated.  But Wall 
20101222015023.000|20101222015025.000|TR0|Street takes, and the mutual fund money 
20101222015025.000|20101222015027.000|TR0|managers and the traders and the marketers 
20101222015027.000|20101222015029.000|TR0|and the lawyers and that whole 
20101222015029.000|20101222015030.000|TR0|constellation --
20101222015030.000|20101222015032.000|TR0|
20101222015032.000|20101222015034.000|TR0|SPITZER:  The deciphers who feed out of 
20101222015034.000|20101222015036.000|TR0|this.
20101222015036.000|20101222015037.000|TR0|
20101222015037.000|20101222015039.000|TR0|BOGLE:  Yes, they're feeding away.  The 
20101222015039.000|20101222015041.000|TR0|rent seekers, they call them.  And they 
20101222015041.000|20101222015043.000|TR0|take about two percent out of that eight 
20101222015043.000|20101222015044.000|TR0|percent, leaving you with six.  And if you 
20101222015044.000|20101222015046.000|TR0|compound that over a lifetime, it means 
20101222015046.000|20101222015048.000|TR0|that you put up 100 percent of the 
20101222015048.000|20101222015050.000|TR0|capital.  You took 100 percent of the risk 
20101222015050.000|20101222015051.000|TR0|and you get about 25 percent of the 
20101222015051.000|20101222015053.000|TR0|return.  And Wall Street puts up none of 
20101222015053.000|20101222015055.000|TR0|the capital.  Takes none of the risk, and 
20101222015055.000|20101222015057.000|TR0|gets 75 percent of the return.  If you 
20101222015057.000|20101222015059.000|TR0|think that's a good deal, Eliot, welcome 
20101222015059.000|20101222015100.000|TR0|to Wall Street.

20101222015111.000|20101222015113.000|TR0|BOGLE:  Exactly.  The mutual fund industry 
20101222015113.000|20101222015114.000|TR0|has become a big marketing industry whose 
20101222015114.000|20101222015116.000|TR0|objective is to raise the amount of assets 
20101222015116.000|20101222015118.000|TR0|under management.  The bigger you are, the 
20101222015118.000|20101222015120.000|TR0|more your fees.  There's a lot of leverage 
20101222015120.000|20101222015121.000|TR0|in those fees and huge economies at scale 
20101222015121.000|20101222015123.000|TR0|as you get bigger.  And the mutual fund 
20101222015123.000|20101222015125.000|TR0|industry by and large has not shared those 
20101222015125.000|20101222015127.000|TR0|economies to scale with investors.  
20101222015127.000|20101222015128.000|TR0|They've shared it with themselves.

20101222015645.000|20101222015647.000|TR0|
20101222015647.000|20101222015649.000|TR0|Federal regulators today voted to adopt 
20101222015649.000|20101222015651.000|TR0|so-called net neutrality rules which 
20101222015651.000|20101222015653.000|TR0|broadly speaking means that all content on 
20101222015653.000|20101222015654.000|TR0|the Internet must be treated equally.  The 
20101222015654.000|20101222015656.000|TR0|rules are designed to keep people who pay 
20101222015656.000|20101222015658.000|TR0|more from getting better web service than 
20101222015658.000|20101222015700.000|TR0|others.  Congress could decide to amend or 
20101222015700.000|20101222015701.000|TR0|weaken those rules.

20101222015705.000|20101222015707.000|TR0|record-breaking snow, rain and flooding

20101222015708.000|20101222015710.000|TR0|emergency tows and crashed vehicles.  More 
20101222015710.000|20101222015712.000|TR0|than 25,000 distraught motorists called

20101222015722.000|20101222015724.000|TR0|brought more frustration and delays.  Two

20101222015806.000|20101222015808.000|TR0|Pennsylvania.

20101222015812.000|20101222015814.000|TR0|Congressman Murphy spoke movingly about a 
20101222015814.000|20101222015815.000|TR0|company commander in Kabul, Afghanistan.  
20101222015815.000|20101222015817.000|TR0|Let's call him "Commander X."  He had 
20101222015817.000|20101222015819.000|TR0|counseled many soldiers who received a

20101222015821.000|20101222015822.000|TR0|But now, "Commander X" needed counseling.  
20101222015822.000|20101222015824.000|TR0|He had no one to turn to except an Iraq

20101222015833.000|20101222015835.000|TR0|REP. PATRICK MURPHY (D), PENNSYLVANIA:  
20101222015835.000|20101222015836.000|TR0|This young company commander, this captain 
20101222015836.000|20101222015838.000|TR0|on his fourth deployment wrote an e-mail 
20101222015838.000|20101222015840.000|TR0|saying I never thought I'd see the day 
20101222015840.000|20101222015842.000|TR0|when I got one of those letters myself.  
20101222015842.000|20101222015843.000|TR0|And I'm sitting here at 3:00 in the 
20101222015843.000|20101222015845.000|TR0|morning in Kabul, Afghanistan, and I have 
20101222015845.000|20101222015847.000|TR0|nowhere to go because I happen to be gay, 
20101222015847.000|20101222015849.000|TR0|and I can't walk into the chaplain. I
